items.title: Glacial meltwater increases coastal carbon dioxide uptake and sensitivity to biogeochemical change
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 22 August 2025

Glacial meltwater increases coastal carbon dioxide uptake and sensitivity to biogeochemical change
                    Henry C. Henson 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-1370-78871,2, Isolde Callisto Puts 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0291-26391,2,3, Mikael K. Sejr 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8370-57911,2, Lise Lotte Sørensen 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-9823-589X2,4 & …Johnna M. Holding 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7364-00551,2,5 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 687 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Carbon cycleClimate changeMarine chemistryOcean sciences

AbstractThe accelerating melt of the Greenland Ice Sheet is releasing large volumes of freshwater into the coastal ocean, diluting seawater alkalinity. Biogeochemical processes such as photosynthesis, respiration, and sediment mineral dissolution also shape carbon dynamics in these freshened waters, but their combined influence on the ocean’s carbon pump remains unresolved. Here we isolate the chemical effects of meltwater dilution through a controlled seawater-freshwater mixing experiment, providing empirical evidence for nonlinear reduction in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2). Carbonate system modeling revealed the mechanisms behind this nonlinearity, helping to explain 17 years of low pCO2 in a Greenlandic fjord. Sensitivity analysis shows that the influence of biogeochemical processes is fundamentally shaped by the chemical environment in which they operate. Freshwater input reduces buffering capacity and therefore amplifies the system’s sensitivity to biological activity and acidification. Our findings highlight how meltwater amplifies biogeochemical control of pCO2 in Arctic coastal systems.

IntroductionThe coastal Arctic ocean plays an outsized role in the global carbon cycle, absorbing atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) at disproportionately high rates per unit area1. As Arctic warming intensifies, freshwater runoff into these coastal zones is accelerating2, altering stratification, circulation3, and biogeochemical cycling4,5,6. In other words, coastal carbon cycling is increasingly shaped by changes in the adjacent catchment’s cryosphere—through surface water dilution or export of sediment and organic matter7,8. Despite mounting evidence that Arctic shelves and fjords are significant CO2 sinks, the mechanisms driving the low partial pressures of CO2 (pCO2) observed in freshwater-influenced regions remain unresolved. Freshwater input, whether derived from rivers, sea ice, precipitation, or glacial melt, can influence CO2 uptake via both biological and chemical pathways. Though, the relative contribution of these pathways remains unclear. In permafrost-dominated catchments, river discharge often delivers terrigenous organic matter that fuels microbial respiration and suppresses net CO2 uptake7,8. In contrast, glacial runoff, though low in organic carbon, can influence nutrient supply, light conditions, and circulation in ways that either stimulate or suppress net ecosystem production5,9.Across the Arctic, from North America to Svalbard and Greenland, these glacially-modified surface waters consistently exhibit low pCO2 levels10,11,12,13,14.While strong primary productivity in Arctic coastal regions has been proposed to explain this pattern13,15,16, chemical mechanisms remain underexplored. One key but poorly understood process is the effect of freshwater dilution on the marine carbonate system. Glacial meltwater, which is low in total alkalinity (TA), reduces the buffering capacity of seawater and alters its sensitivity to changes in dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC). This altered sensitivity leads to nonlinear reductions in pCO2 during seawater-freshwater mixing, yet this behavior has been only briefly described in theoretical or model-based terms16. However, this nonlinearity can take many different shapes (e.g., steadily decreasing or decreasing and then increasing across a salinity gradient), depending on the chemical signature of the freshwater. Indeed, the shape of this nonlinearity has never been described.Here, we investigate the role of chemical dilution in modulating pCO2 by combining 17 years of fjord surface observations with controlled seawater-freshwater mixing experiments and endmember-based mixing models. This approach allows us to isolate the chemical effects of dilution and to describe the mechanisms behind pCO2’s nonlinear behavior. We further explore how shifts in buffering capacity shape the system’s sensitivity to biogeochemical processes. To do this, we introduce a sensitivity factor that quantifies the response of pCO2 to changes in DIC or TA (representing biological activity and mineral effects) under varying dilution conditions. Although the role of ocean buffering has long been recognized17,18, few studies have quantified how this sensitivity evolves across freshwater gradients. By constraining these dynamics in a glacial fjord setting, we provide new insight into the chemical controls on carbon cycling in Arctic coastal ecosystems.Results and DiscussionYoung Sound illustrates consistently low pCO2 in glacially-modified waterFreshwater-enhanced CO2 uptake is evident in Young Sound, a well-studied fjord in North-Eastern Greenland19. Transects along this fjord system reveal strong biogeochemical gradients from the glacially-influenced inner fjord to the marine-dominated outer fjord6 (Fig. 1). As meltwater from the Tyroler River mixes with seawater, salinity along the fjord decreases in a near-linear fashion toward the Greenland Sea (Fig. 1b). This dilution induces corresponding reductions in dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) and total alkalinity (TA), as glacial meltwater, which is inherently low in these compounds, mixes with the more strongly buffered marine waters (i.e., those with higher TA:DIC ratios; Fig. 1c, d). Glacial runoff also contributes substantial amounts of suspended sediment, increasing turbidity and thereby shaping underwater light conditions along the fjord6.Fig. 1: Glacial meltwater reduces salinity and carbonate chemistry parameters across the Young Sound transect.a Map of the Young Sound transect (red line) in Northeast Greenland, spanning from the Greenland Ice Sheet {y} to the Greenland Sea {z}. b–d Section plots along this transect from August 2023 show reductions in (b) salinity, (c) dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC), and (d) total alkalinity (TA) in surface waters due to glacial meltwater runoff. Distance along the x-axis reflects kilometers from the outlet of the Tyroler River, which transports meltwater from the Greenland Ice Sheet into the fjord. Dashes above panel (b) indicate locations of CTD casts. Black points in (c) and (d) represent discrete water sample locations used for interpolation across the transect.Full size imageLong-term pCO2 observations taken at 1 m depth reinforce the dominant role of freshwater in shaping the fjord’s carbon dynamics. Over 17 years, the strongest atmospheric undersaturation observed in the August transects, was consistently located in the inner fjord (Fig. 2b). In other words, where there is most freshwater influence, we observe the most negative ΔpCO2 values. Here:$$\Delta {{\rm{pC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{2}={{\rm{pC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{2,{{\rm{sea}}}}-{{\rm{pC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{2,{{\rm{air}}}}$$
                    (1)
                Fig. 2: Seasonal and long-term ∆pCO2 observations in Young Sound illustrate freshwater influence.a Surface ΔpCO2 along the Young Sound transect (see Fig. 1) during the 2014 open-water season. These data illustrate seasonal differences between peak melt conditions (July-August) and post-melt conditions (September-October). b Time series of August ΔpCO2 measurements from 2007 to 2023 show that 2014 is representative of typical spatial patterns, with the lowest pCO2 levels consistently observed in the inner fjord. c Boxplots of August pCO2 measurements along the transect highlight interannual variability over the 17-year time series.Full size imageThis signal is particularly strong when there is peak melt (July-August), but vanishes in post-melt conditions (September-October), underscoring meltwater’s dominant influence (Fig. 2a).Notably, freshwater content in the fjord has roughly tripled over the past decade20, which would imply that meltwater’s influence on pCO2 dynamics may be intensifying. However, large interannual variability (Fig. 2c), likely representing meltwater pulses in August, make it difficult to observe these trends when monitoring only one month per year. To better understand how glacial meltwater dilution controls ocean pCO2, we conducted controlled seawater-freshwater mixing experiments and constructed mixing models to simulate the effects of freshwater influx in these ecosystems. The range of ∆pCO2 values in 2023 (Fig. 2c) when these mixing experiments were conducted illustrate that this year was representative of long-standing conditions within the fjord.Carbonate system dynamics and nonlinearity in freshened watersAt low salinities, coastal Greenland waters exhibit the chemical signature of glacial meltwater4 (Supplementary Fig. 1). This occurs because concentrations of conservative compounds mix predictably according to their respective end-member values:$${[{{\rm{C}}}]}_{{{\rm{Mix}}}}({{{\rm{M}}}}_{1}+{{{\rm{M}}}}_{2})={[{{\rm{C}}}]}_{1}{{{\rm{M}}}}_{1}+{[{{\rm{C}}}]}_{2}{{{\rm{M}}}}_{2}$$
                    (2)
                where, [C] is the concentration of a compound, and M represents the mass of the water parcels.True conservative properties, such as salinity, change solely through physical processes like mixing or advection. In contrast, non-conservative properties are also altered by biological or chemical processes. Semi-conservative quantities like dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) and total alkalinity (TA) behave conservatively during mixing but are subject to modification by biogeochemical processes (e.g., photosynthesis, respiration, CaCO3 precipitation/dissolution, or gas exchange). DIC represents the sum of inorganic carbon species in solution (H2CO3, HCO3−, CO32−). Meanwhile, titration alkalinity (hereafter total alkalinity or TA) represents the excess of proton acceptors over donors with respect to carbonic acid, the reference level18.$${{\rm{TA}}}= \,	{{\rm{HC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{{3}}^{-}+2{{\rm{C}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{{3}}^{2-}+{{{\rm{OH}}}}^{-}+{{\rm{B}}}{({{\rm{OH}}})}_{{4}}^{-}+{{\rm{HP}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{{4}}^{2-}+2{{\rm{P}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{{4}}^{3-} \\ 	+{{{\rm{H}}}}_{3}{{\rm{Si}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{{4}}^{-}+{{\rm{N}}}{{{\rm{H}}}}_{3}+{{\rm{H}}}{{{\rm{S}}}}^{-}+2{{{\rm{S}}}}^{2-}-{{{\rm{H}}}}^{+} \\ 	-{{\rm{HF}}}-{{\rm{HS}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{{4}}^{-}-{{{\rm{H}}}}_{3}{{\rm{P}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{4}$$
                    (3)
                When glacial meltwater mixes with seawater, both DIC and TA exhibit conservative mixing. That is, their total concentrations vary linearly along a dilution line between freshwater and marine endmembers (Fig. 3a, Supplementary Fig. 1). DIC and TA are summative quantities. DIC encompasses all aqueous CO2 species in equilibrium: CO2, HCO3−, and CO32−, while TA is dominated ( ~ 95%) by carbonate alkalinity: primarily HCO3− and CO32−18. Although the relative proportions of individual species shift in response to freshwater dilution, the total DIC and TA concentrations remain conserved in the absence of biological activity or air-sea CO2 exchange.Fig. 3: Carbonate system changes across salinity gradients in seawater-glacial meltwater mixing experiments.Panel a illustrates the evolution of pCO2, DIC, and TA in seawater + glacial melt dilutions, where pCO2 follows a U-shaped trend, decreasing to a minimum around salinity 9.5 before rising again, in contrast to the linear dilution of DIC and TA. Panel b shows changes in carbonate system speciation (CO2, HCO3−, CO32−) and pH as seawater mixes with glacial meltwater. These shifting concentrations of individual carbonate system species help explain the nonconservative behavior of pCO2. Lines in (a) and (b) represent calculated relationships based on a mixing model, while points indicate pCO2 measured after 24 min of equilibration in physical mixing experiments (Supplementary Fig. 5).Full size imageUnlike TA and DIC, however, pCO2 behaves non-conservatively during mixing. That is, the resulting pCO2 is not a simple average of the endmember values but often shows distinct undersaturation relative to atmospheric concentrations (Figs. 3a and 2b). This nonlinearity has been noted in previous studies, particularly in glacially influenced systems16,21,22, but the shape of the response and the mechanisms driving it remain poorly understood. For example, Horikawa et al. (2022) attribute elevated pCO2 at low salinities to land-derived substances but overlook shifts in the carbonate system itself due to acidification.To better constrain the chemical impacts of Arctic freshening, we replicated seawater-freshwater mixing scenarios in a controlled laboratory setting by mixing seawater and glacial meltwater at different ratios and monitoring changes in pCO2 (Methods). Individually, both seawater and glacial meltwater had relatively high pCO2 levels, close to 400 µatm. However, upon mixing pCO2 reduced dramatically (Fig. 3a, Supplementary Fig. 5). These controlled mixing experiments demonstrated that pCO2 followed a U-shaped curve as salinity decreased from ~31 to 0, providing empirical evidence of pCO2’s nonconservative behavior in the absence of biological or thermal influences.Additionally, we applied endmember-based mixing models to examine the change in pCO2 across a range of freshening conditions beyond what was feasible to measure in the laboratory (Methods, Table 1). The most pronounced pCO2 undersaturation in our mixing model occurs at salinity of ~ 9.5. Here, pCO2 decreases to 204 µatm, reaching an undersaturation of over 200 µatm below atmospheric levels, thus enhancing the fjord’s sink capacity (Fig. 3a). This minimum coincides with the point at which the TA:DIC ratio approaches unity (where TA = DIC). Below this salinity, pCO2 rises markedly, reaching 397 µatm in the glacial melt of Tyroler River. This rise in pCO2 is linked to the continued dilution of TA and the resulting decline in pH. At very low salinities, the water mixture has very low buffering capacity, so when the TA:DIC ratio drops below 1, acidification occurs, shifting the carbonate system toward CO2 (Fig. 3b). While surface water acidification has been observed in many fjord systems around Greenland, whether or not this occurs depends on both the TA:DIC ratio of the meltwater in each catchment and the volume of freshwater discharged4.Table 1 Water endmembers used in the mixing models of this studyFull size tableOur mixing models also allowed us to calculate the full carbonate system along a freshwater dilution gradient, and identify the processes responsible for nonlinear pCO2 behavior in these environments (Fig. 3b). We find that as glacial meltwater enters seawater, the simultaneous decline in DIC and TA alters carbonate speciation and shifts pH. In our mixing model, replicating in-situ pCO2 conditions, glacial meltwater had a lower TA:DIC ratio than seawater (0.87 vs. 1.05; Table 1). Upon mixing, this difference in ratio leads to a slight pH increase at salinities above 10, followed by a sharp decline as dilution progresses (Fig. 3b). The temporary pH increase promotes the conversion of CO2 into HCO3− while the overall DIC pool is diluted. However, this conversion releases H+ ions, which react with resident CO32− ions to maintain charge balance, ultimately reducing CO32− concentrations while increasing HCO3− (Fig. 3b). The net effect is distinct CO2 undersaturation driven by these nonlinear carbonate system responses.To further explore when acidification will occur as well as examine the potential shapes of nonlinearity in pCO2 reduction, we created mixing models with different TA:DIC ratios in the freshwater endmember (Supplementary Fig. 2). When freshwater has a lower TA:DIC ratio than seawater (particularly when TA:DIC < 1), mixing produces a U-shaped pCO2 curve associated with acidification at low salinities. In contrast, if freshwater TA:DIC exceeds that of seawater, the pH change is unidirectionally positive, and minimum pCO2 occurs at a salinity of zero. Thus, the shape of nonlinear pCO2 response is highly determined by the carbonate chemistry of the freshwater endmember.In Young Sound, we clearly observe the U-shaped nonlinearity in pCO2 caused by a freshwater endmember with a TA:DIC ratio lower than that of seawater. In contrast, river runoff in southeastern Hudson Bay has a relatively high TA:DIC ratio, representing a freshwater endmember that could potentially buffer against acidification during mixing. This highlights the natural occurrence of such endmembers, which may increase pH under certain mixing scenarios23. TA:DIC ratios in freshwater systems can vary widely, largely due to catchment characteristics such as geology, vegetation cover, and freshwater residence time. However, a synoptic analysis evaluating the implications of this variability across systems is still lacking.Sensitivity of pCO2 in freshened water to biogeochemical modificationGlacial meltwater enhances the sensitivity of the marine CO2 system to biogeochemical processes by diluting seawater alkalinity. As TA decreases, the buffering capacity of the water parcel weakens, making the system more sensitive to acidification4,18, shifts in biological activity, and mineral dissolution. To quantify this effect, we define a pCO2 sensitivity factor (\({S}_{{{pCO}}_{2}}^{{process}}\)), representing the change in pCO2 per unit perturbation for a given biogeochemical process (e.g., +1 µmol kg−1 DIC from respiration). This metric, derived from endmember-based mixing models, captures how glacial dilution alters the carbonate system’s response to primary production, respiration, and CaCO3 dissolution or precipitation across a salinity-alkalinity gradient (Methods; Fig. 4a, b). While conceptually related to the Revelle factor, this approach provides process-specific sensitivities, enabling direct comparison across dynamic seawater-freshwater mixing regimes.Fig. 4: Process-specific pCO2 sensitivity factors across seawater-freshwater mixing gradients.Panels a and b illustrate the sensitivity of surface water pCO2 (\({S}_{{{pCO}}_{2}}^{{process}}\)) to biogeochemical processes along an observed salinity and alkalinity gradient. a shows the change in pCO2 due addition or removal of 1 µmol kg−1 O2, simulating idealized photosynthesis or respiration based on Redfield stoichiometry (−1:1 O2:DIC). Meanwhile, b depicts pCO2 sensitivity to precipitation or dissolution of 1 µmol kg−1 CaCO3, assuming a 2:1 TA:DIC ratio. Calculations of these sensitivity factors are based on an idealied mixing model (Methods, Supplementary Fig. 6). These results demonstrate that glacially-modified waters, with diluted alkalinity, are much more sensitive to biogeochemical processing than undiluted marine waters.Full size imageThese sensitivity factors reveal that biological processes such as photosynthesis and respiration can exert amplified effects in low-alkalinity, glacially influenced waters. For example, during periods of primary production, the reduced alkalinity of the freshened surface ocean amplifies the biological drawdown of pCO2 (Fig. 4a), particularly as peak melt often coincides with summer light conditions. Likewise, pCO2 would increase disproportionally when bacterial respiration occurs in glacially modified water (Fig. 4a). In Young Sound, the effect of biological production doubles and then triples as salinity (and therefore alkalinity) decreases from oceanic to coastal ( ~18) and estuarine levels ( ~ 10; Supplementary Fig. 3). This is because, in this effectively unbuffered ecosystem, relatively smaller production rates and their smaller changes in DIC cause larger shifts in the carbonate system.A similar amplification occurs for abiotic processes. For example, mineral precipitation or dissolution can also impact surface water pCO2 levels11. Glacial catchments export large quantities of fine sediment particles, providing reactive surfaces that promote water-mineral interactions. However, the impact of sediment export depends strongly on catchment geology. Carbonate-rich rocks can contribute additional TA through carbonate dissolution, contrasting with silicate-dominated catchments, which dissolve less readily24,25. The transport and dissolution of CaCO3 increases both TA and DIC at a ratio of 2 to 1:So:$${{\rm{CaC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{3} \to {{{\rm{Ca}}}}^{2+}+{{\rm{C}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{3}^{2-}$$
                    (4)
                Or:$${{\rm{CaC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{3}+{{\rm{C}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{2}+{{{\rm{H}}}}_{2}{{\rm{O}}}\to {{{\rm{Ca}}}}^{2+}+2{{\rm{HC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{3}^{-}$$
                    (5)
                This alkalinity addition relative to DIC will raise the pH and lower the pCO2, creating more intense undersaturation than would otherwise be reached (Fig. 4b).The geological setting of Young Sound supports this mechanism. The terrestrial catchment includes carbonate rocks, resistant crystalline formations (gneiss, granite, schist), and sedimentary layers with basaltic intrusions. Carbonate formations are particularly prone to weathering, delivering fine, calcareous sediments to the coastal zone26. In August 2023, we measured that Tyroler River exported 0.25 grams of sediment per liter of freshwater. To assess whether this sediment influences freshwater alkalinity, we conducted a simple experiment: glacial sediment added to Milli-Q water increased TA linearly over 24 h (TA = 98 + 0.89 h, R2 = 0.97, p < 0.001; Supplementary Fig. 4) indicating that glacial silt can elevate TA by releasing proton acceptors into solution.Over the course of one day, exported sediment could contribute ~21 µmol kg−1 of TA to the water parcel. While the effects of this change would be minimal ( ~1%) in undiluted Young Sound seawater (average TA = 2244 µmol kg−1), it represents a substantial relative increase under freshwater-dominated conditions. As previously shown in our mixing model experiments, even modest changes to the freshwater alkalinity endmember can alter the TA:DIC ratio, which governs the shape and behavior of the carbonate system during mixing. These nonlinear behaviors underscore how sedimentary processes may modify carbonate system trajectories in glacially influenced coastal zones. However, further work clarifying the true alkalinity change from sediment export is needed.Freshwater can also transport terrestrially derived organic matter into coastal waters. This organic matter is dominated by humic substances that contain carboxylic and phenolic functional groups, which may supply organic alkalinity27,28. However, given the sparse vegetation cover, short distance from the glacier to the fjord, and predominantly mineral-based geology, the present contribution of organic alkalinity in Young Sound is likely minimal. Indeed, Tyroler River freshwater contains very low concentrations of dissolved organic carbon29, suggesting a negligible organic influence on total alkalinity under current conditions. Nonetheless, it is important to recognize that dissolved organic matter can exert complex effects on the carbonate system, both by providing acid-base sites and by influencing CO2 dynamics and pH through remineralization processes. Future shifts in catchment vegetation, permafrost thaw, or longer freshwater residence times could increase the export of reactive organic matter to coastal waters, potentially altering buffering capacity and CO2 exchange in low-salinity waters22.Together, these sedimentary and organic processes illustrate how natural alkalinity sources can modulate carbonate system dynamics on local scales. Notably, these same principles underpin ocean alkalinity enhancement (OAE), a proposed geoengineering strategy for marine carbon dioxide removal. By artificially adding alkalinity (e.g., through mineral dissolution), OAE increases the buffering capacity of seawater, which raises pH and lowers pCO2, thereby enhancing CO2 uptake from the atmosphere. In effect, this engineered approach mimics natural processes like weathering, coastal erosion, and sediment dissolution, which already contribute to carbon drawdown in ocean environments30.Whether naturally occurring or not, these sediment effects would only be heightened in glacial meltwater plumes. When DIC and TA are already reduced, the same amount of added alkalinity results in stronger pCO2 reduction compared to when the ocean is undiluted (Fig. 4b). In other words, the impact of biogeochemical processes on pCO2 (and pH) depends on the system’s sensitivity18, where glacially-modified water is a highly sensitive environment to perturbations.Implications of high latitude freshwater export on the marine CO2 systemOn a pan-Arctic scale, surface ocean pCO2 dynamics are governed by three dominant processes. First, freshwater input, whether from glacial melt or river discharge, lowers pCO2 via dilution of total inorganic carbon. Second, biogeochemical processing, modulated by light, nutrients, and organic or sediment loads from a changing cryosphere31, can enhance or offset this uptake potential. Third, sea ice loss can extend the open water season, increasing the window for air-sea CO2 exchange while contributing additional freshwater. Our results reveal that freshwater dilution is involved in or impacts all three of these dominant pathways.By constraining all individual inorganic carbon species in the marine CO2 system, we demonstrate the mechanisms behind dilution-driven nonlinearity in pCO2. Because these mechanisms arise from fundamental carbonate chemistry, they are not regionally specific. Similar nonlinear pCO2 dynamics likely shape coastal CO2 uptake across diverse polar and subpolar systems including the coasts of Chile, Alaska, Svalbard, Antarctica, and Greenland – where strong undersaturation has also been observed10,11,12,13,16,21,32,33.Furthermore, we show that the impact of biogeochemical processes is fundamentally shaped by the chemical environment in which they occur. Where freshwater runoff dilutes alkalinity, pCO2 and pH become more sensitive to changes in TA or DIC. In the Arctic, signs of freshening are already evident, including longer freshwater export seasons and rising meltwater concentrations34. While Arctic river alkalinity is higher than that of glacial melt, it remains substantially lower than seawater ( ~ 1000 vs. ~2200 µmol kg−1)22,35, suggesting that continued increases in freshwater delivery will generally reduce the buffering capacity of Arctic coastal waters. However, trends toward rising alkalinity in some Arctic rivers, due to climate-driven changes in vegetation, permafrost thaw, and hydrological pathways36, could partially offset this loss of buffering capacity. Still, as runoff and melt accelerate, the coastal Arctic will likely become more diluted in alkalinity, resulting in surface waters increasingly susceptible to biogeochemical change. Reduced buffering capacity will amplify the effect of Arctic processes on air-sea CO2 exchange, whether from biological activity, enhanced erosion, or future geoengineering interventions.Overall, the balance between dilution-driven sensitivity and buffering from evolving riverine inputs will vary with regional geology, catchment type, and cryospheric change. As a result, Arctic coastal CO2 uptake will likely respond to climate change along a distinct trajectory and pace compared to the open Arctic Ocean.MethodsField Sampling in Young SoundThe study was conducted in Young Sound (74°18′N, 20°18′W), a high-Arctic fjord located in northeast Greenland (Fig. 1a). This fjord spans 90 km, with a width ranging from 2 to 7 km, covering a total area of 390 km2. The Greenland Ice sheet connects to this fjord system via the Tyroler River leading to freshened surface salinities (1 m) ranging between 6.6 to 28 in August 2023. Along the Young Sound transect, vertical profiles of temperature, and salinity were measured on a RBR CTD. Additionally, water samples were collected at depths of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 30, 50, and 100, and 150 meters using a 5-L Niskin bottle.From 2007 through 2023, sea-surface pCO2 was measured at a depth of 1 m along a transect conducted each August, extending from the glacially-modified inner fjord to the Greenland Sea. Sampling was carried out using a small boat without a water intake system, necessitating manual collection of water samples from both the surface and at depth. From 2007 to 2014, pCO2 was measured using an EGM-4 infrared CO2 analyzer (PP Systems). Seawater was pumped from 1 m depth through 2 meters of Tygon tubing into a membrane-based equilibrator (Mini Module, Liqui-Cel, Charlotte, NC, USA) at an approximate flow rate of 2 L per minute37. In this closed-loop system, dissolved CO2 in the seawater equilibrated with a confined gas volume across a gas-permeable membrane. This gas ( ~ 200 mL at ambient pressure) was continuously cycled through a Drierite drying column and into the CO2 analyzer, before being recirculated into the equilibrator. The CO2 analyzer was calibrated daily against reference gases with known CO2 levels, maintaining a precision of ±2 ppm. Atmospheric CO2 levels were also measured 5 to 10 times during each summer sampling period by pumping air through a Tygon tube positioned 3 meters above the sea surface, routed directly through the drying column into the CO2 analyzer.In 2014, the EGM4 infrared CO2 analyzer was replaced with a Contros Hydro-C CO2 sensor. This allowed for vertical profiling of pCO2 beyond surface measurements. Since 2014, seawater pCO2 profiles have been collected at 8 depths ranging from 1 to 60 meters (1 m, 5 m, 10 m, 20 m, 30 m, 40 m, 50 m, 60 m). The Hydro-C sensor was lowered over the side of the vessel, left to equilibrate for 5–10 min at each depth until measurements stabilized. To minimize surface disturbances, the vessel’s engines were turned off during sampling at each station. The HydroC sensor was calibrated annually using a certified 400 ± 2 ppm CO2 gas standard and consistently demonstrated accuracy within 397–401 ppm, indicating negligible drift and eliminating the need for post-correction. A precision of ±2 ppm was assumed for both the EGM-4 and HydroC systems.The year 2014 was unique in that the Young Sound transect was sampled outside of August. An extended field campaign during the four-month open-water season allowed for monthly repetitions of the transect, illustrating differences between peak-melt and post-melt conditions.Chemical AnalysisWater samples from all depths along the fjord transect were analyzed for carbonate chemistry parameters. For DIC and TA measurements, samples were transferred directly from the Niskin bottles into triplicate 12 mL exetainers via gas-tight Tygon tubing, allowing an overflow of at least three times the exetainer’s volume. Triplicates were collected at each depth for both DIC and TA. Samples were preserved with HgCl2 (saturated solution) to reach a final concentration of 0.02%. DIC was measured using an Apollo SciTech AS-C3 analyzer38, which combines an acidification and purging system with a LI-COR 7000 CO2 gas detector. The instrument was calibrated every 24 h using certified reference materials (CRMs; batch 184, provided by A.G. Dickson, Scripps Institution of Oceanography). Total alkalinity was measured by potentiometric titration39 using an Apollo SciTech AS-ALK2 titrator. The titrant solution was characterized by titration against CRMs (batch 184) prior to each batch of sample analysis. To account for potential drift, CRMs were analyzed for both DIC and TA after every three samples. Analytical precision, calculated as the median standard deviation of triplicate fjord water samples, was ± 2.5 μmol kg−1 for DIC and ± 8.5 μmol kg−1 for TA.To examine whether glacial sediments have the potential to elevate alkalinity in freshwater, we conducted a silt addition experiment during fieldwork in Young Sound. Glacial meltwater from the Tyroler River was first filtered sequentially using 3 µm and 0.4 µm IsoporeTM PC membrane filters to quantify the suspended sediment load. The removed silt (size fractions: 0.23 g L−1 > 3 µm, 0.02 g L−1 > 0.4–3 µm) was then added to Milli-Q (MQ) water to isolate the effects of mineral dissolution without background alkalinity. The mixture was vigorously shaken and allowed to stand for 1, 3, 6, 12, or 24 h. At each time point, the sediment was removed using the same filtration technique, and triplicate samples were taken for TA analysis, following the method above (Supplementary Fig. 4).This experiment was designed as a first-order test of the potential for calcareous sediments to release alkalinity to freshwater. While not directly representative of in situ meltwater conditions, using MQ water allowed us to detect alkalinity generation from silt dissolution against the lowest possible alkalinity baseline. Future work should include collecting and adding silt to glacial meltwater directly, extending the duration beyond 24 h, and characterizing the mineralogical composition of the sediment to better assess its geochemical reactivity. Despite its limitations, the experiment supports the possibility that sediment interactions can influence TA in glacial outflows and freshwater-dominated coastal waters.Mixing experimentTo investigate the effects of glacial runoff on the physical and chemical processes within the fjord, a series of mixing experiments were conducted. These experiments involved diluting seawater with freshwater, simulating the gradient of freshwater influx from glacial melt. Seawater was sourced from the standard station (74.310, -20.300) within the fjord at a depth of 30 meters, below the influence of surface freshwater stratification. Glacial meltwater was collected from the Tyroler River (74.606, -22.094) which transports melt from the Greenland Ice Sheet into the inner fjord region.For the physical and chemical assessments, seawater was diluted with freshwater to 0%, 10%, 30%, and 50% and 100% of the total volume, representing a range of dilution scenarios. To standardize temperature conditions, premixed samples were stored in an ice bath to bring them down to 0 °C. The samples were then mixed in a 10-L carboy, filled without headspace, and circulated in a closed loop with Tygon tubing through a Contros Hydro-C CO2 sensor with a flow-through head. This setup allowed for real-time monitoring of pCO2 immediately upon mixing for a set duration of 1 h (Supplementary Fig. 5). Measured pCO2 changed rapidly upon mixing, but remained stable after ~24 min, allowing the notation of a pCO2 value after full mixing but before slight heating from the sensor could impact the measurement. After the one hour of pCO2 monitoring was complete, subsamples were collected from the carboy to analyze DIC and TA following the method above.Meltwater-Seawater Mixing Model and Carbonate chemistry calculationsA seawater-freshwater mixing model was constructed using endmember chemical concentrations and physical parameters listed in Table 1. This model enabled us to explore the evolution of the marine carbonate system across a range of mixing ratios that go beyond what is feasible to replicate in the laboratory. Because salinity, DIC, and TA mix conservatively, we applied a linear dilution between the seawater and freshwater endmembers. From the resulting linear gradients in DIC and TA, we calculated the remaining carbonate system parameters, including individual inorganic carbon species, which cannot be directly measured. Carbonate system calculations were performed in R using the seacarb package40 using K1 and K2 carbonate equilibria constants from Lueker et al. (2000)41 as recommended by Dickson et al. (2007)38, and total boron formulation from Lee et al. (2010)42. Furthermore, this allows consistency with prior regional studies on ocean acidification and CO2 dynamics4.Measured pCO2 values, however, did not align with those predicted from DIC and TA endmembers (Supplementary Fig. 2c). Consequently, the mixing model produced pCO2 values along a skewed dilution curve when compared to laboratory measurements. Such discrepancies are well-documented in ecosystems where carbonate equilibrium constants are poorly constrained, such as Arctic coastal regions43,44,45. Equilibrium constants describing the dissociation equilibria between inorganic carbon species are typically derived from laboratory experiments. Currently, no equilibrium constants fully reflect the low salinity and cold temperatures typical of Arctic environments. Temperature has a significant influence on these thermodynamic constants46. Sulpis et al. (2020) demonstrated that at temperatures below 8 °C, use of the Lueker et al. (2000) constants may result in pCO2 underestimation. While Sulpis et al. (2020) developed their own low-temperature K1 and K2 values, their constants are derived from salinities between ~31 and 38—well outside the salinity range (0–31) of our freshwater-seawater mixtures. Recalculating pCO2 using the Sulpis constants did not resolve the observed mismatch.Further improvement of internal consistency could be achieved in future work by using other carbonate system parameters, such as high-precision pH, instead of TA and DIC. Indeed, the total uncertainty in calculated carbonate parameters often exceeds the analytical precision of the measurements themselves and depends heavily on the chosen input pair (e.g., TA & DIC vs. pH & DIC)43,44. Additional sources of mismatch may include CO2 intrusion from the atmosphere or unaccounted-for warming of water samples during laboratory mixing. Finally, the analytical precision for TA and DIC was larger than that of pCO2. As small absolute deviations in the glacial endmember cause large pCO2 changes, this could be another source of the discrepancy.Despite the observed mismatch, the mixing model remains a valuable tool. One objective of this study was to better understand the drivers and shape of the nonlinear response of pCO2 to glacial meltwater dilution. By calculating the full inorganic carbon system, we show that shifts in pH and carbon speciation underlie the observed nonlinear changes in pCO2. To further investigate this, we estimated DIC from measured pCO2 and TA in order to generate a mixing model that was representative of what was measured in the laboratory experiment (Table 1). When DIC in the glacial meltwater and seawater endmembers was slightly increased (by 29 and 57 µmol kg−1, equivalent to 15% and 2.8%, respectively), calculated pCO2 values matched the measured values across both endmembers and all intermediate dilution points. Crucially, both the model and measurements demonstrate the same pattern—namely, that mixing glacial meltwater with seawater results in a nonlinear pCO2 reduction.To explore the form of this nonlinearity, we further modified the mixing model by adjusting only the DIC of the glacial meltwater endmember to create TA:DIC ratios that were lower than, similar to, and greater than those of seawater (Supplementary Fig. 2). This illustrated nonlinear reduction can have a range of shapes and that a pCO2 increase in low-salinity waters is linked to acidification of the water parcel associated with TA:DIC ratio below 1.Sensitivity AnalysisTo evaluate the sensitivity of surface water pCO2 to biogeochemical perturbations in glacially influenced environments, we developed an approach that isolates the impact of individual processes, such as primary production, microbial respiration, and calcium carbonate (CaCO3) dissolution or precipitation, along a salinity-alkalinity gradient. In this study, we define this response metric as a sensitivity factor (i.e., the tendency to change), following the convention in Middelburg et al. (2020) and related studies, where the cause of change (the process-driven perturbation) is in the denominator and the resulting change in pCO2 is in the numerator. This contrasts with buffering capacities (resistance to change), which are often expressed as the inverse.We can define a process-related pCO2 sensitivity factor as:$${S}_{{{pCO}}_{2}}^{{process}}=\frac{{\partial {pCO}}_{2}}{\partial X}$$
                    (6)
                where X represents the perturbation imposed by each biogeochemical process (encompassing changes in DIC and/or TA), and the partial derivative indicates that all other properties are held constant. This formulation is conceptually related to the sensitivity factors described by Frankignoulle (1994), who quantified the partial derivative of pCO2 with respect to DIC and TA separately47. However, to more accurately represent the combined effects of biogeochemical processes, we follow the approach of Sundquist and Plummer (1981), applying simultaneous changes in both DIC and TA consistent with carbonate stoichiometry48. Although the sensitivity factor is defined as a partial derivative, in practice we estimate it via finite differences:$${S}_{{{pCO}}_{2}}^{{process}}=\,\frac{{\Delta {pCO}}_{2,{process}}}{\Delta X}$$
                    (7)
                Where ∆ X is the size of the perturbation (e.g., +1 µmol kg−1 DIC for respiration), and \({S}_{{{pCO}}_{2}}^{{process}}\) has units of µatm per µmol kg−1. The finite difference in pCO2 for each biogeochemical process is then:$$\Delta {{\rm{pC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{2,{{\rm{process}}}}={{\rm{pC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{2,{{\rm{perturbed}}}}-{{\rm{pC}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}_{2,{{\rm{reference}}}}$$
                    (8)
                This formulation captures the local (absolute) response of pCO2 per unit biogeochemical change along a dilution gradient, accounting for variations in alkalinity and buffering capacity.To estimate these sensitivity factors independent of the nonlinear effects of mixing, we constructed a linear mixing model between two endmembers: glacial meltwater and oceanic seawater. Along this salinity gradient, we assumed a linear relationship between salinity and TA, based on conservative mixing between endmember values. We then calculated the baseline DIC concentrations required to maintain a constant pCO2 (e.g., 402 µatm) along the TA-salinity gradient—i.e., the isoline in a Deffeyes Diagram (Supplementary Fig. 6). We then introduced process-specific perturbations to this baseline system. Primary production and respiration were simulated by removing or adding 1 µmol kg−1 DIC, respectively, with no change in TA. Meanwhile, CaCO3 precipitation and dissolution were modeled as removal or addition of DIC and TA in a 1:2 ratio (1 µmol kg−1 DIC: 2 µmol kg−1 TA), consistent with carbonate stoichiometry.For each perturbation, we recalculated pCO2 using the perturbed DIC and TA values while holding temperature, salinity, and pressure constant. The difference between this perturbed pCO2 and the reference yielded a pCO2 sensitivity factor, \({S}_{{{pCO}}_{2}}^{{process}}\) at each point along the mixing gradient (Fig. 4a, b).Reporting summaryFurther information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article.
